content.text: SNIPER: compress - File & Folder Compression Tool

text: A versatile C-based compression tool supporting both [bold]ZIP[/] archives (via libzip) and
various [bold]TAR[/] archive formats (gzip, bzip2, xz). It automatically detects the desired
TAR format from the output filename extension.
[green]-d, --directory <path>[/]   Directory to compress.
[green]-o, --output <file>[/]      Output file name (e.g., archive.zip, backup.tar.gz).
[green]-l, --level <0-9>[/]        Compression level (0=none, 9=max). Default is system default.
[green]-f, --filter <.ext>[/]      Only include files with this extension (e.g., [cyan].txt[/]).
[green]-e, --exclude <.ext>[/]      Exclude files with this extension (e.g., [cyan].log[/]).
[green]-H, --skip-hidden[/]        Skip hidden files and folders (names starting with '.').
[green]-t, -c, --test[/]         Test the ZIP archive's integrity after creation.
[green]-C, --compression <type>[/]  Explicitly set TAR compression type. Not usually needed.
[dim]Choices: [cyan]gzip, bzip2, xz[/]. Auto-detected from filename.[/]
[green]-v, --verbose[/]            Enable verbose mode to see file processing details.
[green]-h, --help[/]               Show this help message and exit.
[#] Create a standard ZIP archive with verbose output:
[yellow]compress[/] [green]-d ./my_project -o my_archive.zip -v[/]
[#] Create a ZIP including only .c and .h files with maximum compression:
[yellow]compress[/] [green]-d src/ -o source.zip -l 9 -f .c -f .h[/] [dim](Note: use -f multiple times)[/]
[#] Create a compressed TAR archive using bzip2 (auto-detected):
[yellow]compress[/] [green]-d project_files -o backup.tar.bz2[/]
[#] Create a ZIP archive and verify its integrity:
[yellow]compress[/] [green]-d important_data -o data.zip -t[/]
